title: Sadipur Kotwa
text:
Sadipur Kotwa is a village in <a href="Dih%2C%20Raebareli">Dih</a> block of <a href="Rae%20Bareli%20district">Rae Bareli district</a>, <a href="Uttar%20Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>, <a href="India">India</a>. It is located 20 km from <a href="Raebareli">Raebareli</a>, the district headquarters. As of 2011, it has a population of 1,850 people, in 320 households. It has one primary school and no healthcare facilities, and it does not host a permanent market or weekly <a href="haat">haat</a>. It belongs to the <a href="nyaya%20panchayat">nyaya panchayat</a> of Dih.
The <a href="1951%20Census%20of%20India">1951 census</a> recorded Sadipur Kotwa as comprising 5 hamlets, with a total population of 600 people (312 male and 288 female), in 120 households and 110 physical houses. The area of the village was given as 559 <a href="acre">acre</a>s. 17 residents were literate, 16 male and 1 female. The village was listed as belonging to the <a href="pargana">pargana</a> of <a href="Parshadepur">Parshadepur</a> and the <a href="thana">thana</a> of <a href="Nasirabad%2C%20Raebareli">Nasirabad</a>.
The <a href="1961%20Census%20of%20India">1961 census</a> recorded Sadipur Kotwa as comprising 4 hamlets, with a total population of 638 people (337 male and 301 female), in 130 households and 122 physical houses. The area of the village was given as 559 acres.
The <a href="1981%20Census%20of%20India">1981 census</a> recorded Sadipur Kotwa as having a population of 904 people, in 241 households, and having an area of 234.32 <a href="hectare">hectare</a>s. The main staple foods were listed as wheat and rice.
The <a href="1991%20Census%20of%20India">1991 census</a> recorded Sadipur Kotwa as having a total population of 1,054 people (549 male and 505 female), in 211 households and 209 physical houses. The area of the village was listed as 234 hectares. Members of the 0-6 age group numbered 179, or 17% of the total; this group was 50% male (90) and 50% female (89). Members of <a href="scheduled%20castes">scheduled castes</a> made up 22% of the village's population, while no members of <a href="scheduled%20tribes">scheduled tribes</a> were recorded. The <a href="literacy%20rate">literacy rate</a> of the village was 18% (173 men and 18 women). 323 people were classified as main workers (300 men and 23 women), while 0 people were classified as marginal workers; the remaining 731 residents were non-workers. The breakdown of main workers by employment category was as follows: 303 cultivators (i.e. people who owned or leased their own land); 6 agricultural labourers (i.e. people who worked someone else's land in return for payment); 0 workers in livestock, forestry, fishing, hunting, plantations, orchards, etc.; 0 in mining and quarrying; 1 household industry worker; 1 worker employed in other <a href="manufacturing">manufacturing</a>, processing, service, and repair roles; 0 <a href="construction%20worker">construction worker</a>s; 3 employed in trade and commerce; 1 employed in transport, storage, and communications; and 8 in other services.
